content.description:
Waterboarding starts just left of

Interrogation

.  This technical, 90 foot route has three distinct cruxes (the roof band, the headwall, and the exit moves through the final hang / groove).  Although the route has good rests, the climbing is surprisingly engaging.  Climb blocky / broken rock to a high first clip (or stick clip); power through the roof / hang via small but positive holds; a technical section on the headwall yields the second crux; rest and then exit via the black overhung groove directly above.
content.location:
It is between

East Germany

and

Interrogation

.

content.description:
This is the leftmost route on Berlin Wall, starting on black rock just right of the gully/crack. Rossiter's book shows it as only having one bolt, but there are four (maybe some were added later, though all the hardware looks old). Multiple tricky cruxes, balancey, and technical.

You'll encounter a long runout above the last bolt (we only TR'ed it, but it looks spicy) -- though you could clip the last bolt on Dachau for further protection up high.

Perfect rock, though the top is quite licheny and needs traffic/brushing. A great pitch. Four bolts to ring-and-chain anchors up over the ledge. Not exactly easy for the grade.
content.location: Far left side of the Berlin Wall, just right of the corner/gully.

content.description:
Just to be different...this is a link-up of

Interrogation

through its 8th bolt (last stainless bolt) and finishing on

Waterboarding

. Perhaps someone had done this prior to my ascent? Just seems like a logical line to me....

Withstand all of the cruxes of

Interrogation

, but instead of forcing the last "hard right" move and clipping its 9th bolt follow the obvious weaknesses up and left via incipient cracks. Get a good rest and finish on

Waterboarding's

final crux through the black groovy bulge. In my opinion, this is an interesting and more continuous version of

Interrogation

.
content.protection:
12 pre-existing bolts.

Possibly bring an optional thin hand piece (compared to the rest of the climbing it is a bit spicy (but not too hard) if you don't get gear in the link, but I did not have a rack when I led it).

content.description:
Interrogation is on the Berlin Wall, and starts just left and uphill from

Blitzkrieg

.  Climb straight up steep and blocky rock; pull the roof (11c/d), step right and climb up to a good rest on the left (12a).  Head up and right onto a steep layback corner/ramp.Layback for several feet; then make a series of very difficult moves up and hard right (12c) until the climbing eases off. Climb up easy rock clipping one last bolt before the anchors.
content.location:
On the Berlin Wall, it starts just left and uphill from

Blitzkrieg

.

content.description: Fall of the Wall is located on the Berlin Wall, with occupies the amphitheater between the Krishna Buttress and Wall of Winter Warmth.  Approach via the steep gully that climbs to the terrace at the base of the Wall if approaching from Boulder Falls, or rappel in from the top if approaching from Upper Dream Canyon parking area.  Fall of the Wall starts circa 20 feet to the right of Iron Curtain.  Ascend the black water streak up to the thin-holds crux between bolts 2 and 3 and follow bolts up and slightly left over the left-facing corner/rooflet onto the tricky headwall (11+) above.

Ascend steep, blocky rock to a knee-bar rest under the large roof/prow (12a).  Launch into a series of very bouldery (V8/9) moves to get established on the exposed prow; finish with 30 feet of enjoyable 11a climibing.
content.protection: 10 bolts (extend draw #5); Fixe traditional ring anchor.
content.location:
This is 20 feet right of

Interrogation

(12+).

content.description:
Any escape from East Germany was difficult since you had to climb over the Berlin Wall.

East Germany is located on the Berlin Wall, which occupies the amphitheater between the Krishna Buttress and Wall of Winter Warmth.  Approach via the steep gully that climbs to the terrace at the base of the Wall if approaching from Boulder Falls, or rap in from the top if approaching from Upper Dream Canyon parking area.  Start East Germany by clipping the first bolt on Fall of the Wall and diagonal up and right to the vertical line of bolts and the route's technical layback/crimp crux (13a).  The climbing eases off until the final (11d/12a) section under the roof overhang.

Dachau was retro-bolted in 2017 with the permission of the first ascent party after a key hold broke on the most runout section of the original line which was done in 1984 with only one bolt.

Look for a positive crimp to clip from just inches right of the 2nd bolt. It is a bit runout above the 6th bolt, but the climbing is easy at that point and not nearly as run as the first ascent on gear.

The original 5.11a trad line shared the start with Iron Curtain just to the right then moved left along a dirty line of weakness near the top. The sport route adds a direct start as well as a cleaner direct finish and bumps the grade up a little.

It was a bold effort by the FA party to do this line with one bolt! As a sport climb, it's excellent power endurance climbing and as good as anything else on this stacked wall.
content.protection:
7 bolts to a new anchor at the top of the wall.

The original version of this line was lead with 1 bolt and gear at 11-, avoiding the direct start and finish.
content.location: It is the second bolted line from the left on the Berlin Wall.

content.description:
One might think that at a wall with mostly 11s and 12s, the 5.10 down at the end might be a good warm-up. This is not always the case. C.C. is a bit physical and also a head-game.

I did a few laps on this one to clean it, and at this point, the route offers mostly good protection, mostly good rock, and a crux with flaring fingerlocks above a somewhat suspect flake into an off-balance overhang. The bush in the crux hand-crack is (mostly) gone, and I tested the flake as much as I was willing to with my belayer below, and it seems reasonably solid.

Start down and right on the wall, climbing a few face moves up the left side of a blunt arete to reach that crack. Establish yourself in said crack, and follow it to its end at an upward-protruding, 2" thick flake the size of a TV set. Get up and onto this, protect the crack above (1.25-1.5" cam), and do the awkward and "engaging" crux to make a transition onto the left wall. A hand-sized cam is handy to have as you exit the crux. Continue on up easier moves and within reach of a few of the bolts of

Checkpoint Bravo

to the left, keeping an eye out on the right for the shared bolted anchor for both routes.
content.protection:
A trad rack from 0.5-3.5" with doubles in 1.5-2.5" cams (2x purple to yellow Camalots) and a few longer slings.

The anchor up top is bolts with chains and requires a few extra slings.
content.location: At the far right side of Berlin Wall, the main wall is capped by a let-facing dihedral. The wall that forms this corner has a diagonal crack running up and left through it that joins the corner at a bulge. Checkpoint Charlie ascends the left-leaning crack and flake system to intercept the dihedral at a bulge. Climb this to an anchor just below the top of the wall on the right side of the corner.

content.description:
Mostly a jug haul, Checkpoint Bravo is probably the best bet for a warm-up as the holds are open handed unlike the crimpy

Walpurgisnacht

(11a). Climb broken rock to a fun roof (black and white rock), pull through using key underclings - it is slightly runout to the next bolt and chains.

climbs.name: Blitzkreig
climbs.fa: FA: Bob Horan and Dan Hare, 1984.

content.description: Climb the obtuse, left-facing corner system, via a bolt, small wires, and Friends.  Climb up to the bolt and move right under the bulge to the corner system.
content.location: Located on the Berlin Wall, a seculded, sheer wall, left of the Wall of Winter Warmth's towering south face.  Hike up to Wall of Winter Warmth's far left side and locate a gully leading up to a ledge with a steep black and white streaked face.
